answerFeedback.655bd156-3707-4626-b0f2-c13da925a48f: Correct because Jaafar's "pump-priming" strategy violates Standard II (B), Market Manipulation, which states that Members and Candidates must not engage in practices that distort prices or artificially inflate trading volume with the intent to mislead market participants. The formal liquidity of a market is determined by the obligations set on market makers, but the actual liquidity of a market is better estimated by the actual trading volume and bid–ask spreads. Attempts to mislead participants about the actual liquidity of the market constitute a violation of Standard II (B). In this example, investors have been intentionally misled to believe they chose the most liquid instrument for some specific purpose, but they could eventually see the actual liquidity of the contract significantly reduced after the term of the agreement expires. If Jaafar were to fully discloses its agreement with members to boost transactions over some initial launch period, he would not violate Standard II (B). Jaafar's intent is not to harm investors but, on the contrary, to give them a better service. For that purpose, he may engage in a liquidity-pumping strategy, but the strategy must be disclosed.
answerFeedback.964c9860-ce4a-42b2-9983-3e78959dbc49: Incorrect because according to Standard III (B), Fair dealing, Members and Candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. There is no information in the vignette to suggest that Jaafar has violated Standard III (B).

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to fair dealing
C. Yes, the Standard relating to market manipulation

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05053
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is a recommended procedure for compliance with the Standard relating to performance presentation? Members should encourage their firms to:

answerFeedback.387738d5-c891-40e9-a08e-3fdb095872d5: Incorrect because it contradicts recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, which include considering the knowledge and sophistication of the audience to whom a performance presentation is addressed. Thus, the recommendation is not to use identical performance presentation reports for all types of clients but to use different reports for different types of clients.
answerFeedback.701ae00d-7edc-472c-a532-9258b6a01932: Correct because recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, include disclosures that fully explain the performance results being reported (for example, stating, when appropriate, that results are simulated when model results are used).
answerFeedback.93b9cf0a-4794-4fff-957d-c249287649aa: Incorrect because it contradicts recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, which include presenting the performance of the weighted composite of similar portfolios rather than using a single representative account.

choices.itemBody: A. state, when applicable, that performance results are simulated.
B. use a representative account to present composite performance.
C. use identical performance presentation reports for all types of clients.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 08EWL
entry.itemBody: Adam Johnson, CFA, works at a large investment firm. After losing his taxi receipt for a business meeting, he uses his colleague’s taxi receipt of a slightly higher value to submit his monthly expense claim to his employer. Recently, Johnson declared personal bankruptcy due to large medical bills for a family member. Has Johnson violated the Standard relating to misconduct?

answerFeedback.0ccba3c0-24ef-47a6-b5fa-4329fba3ca67: Correct because Standard I (D), Misconduct, states that Members must not engage in any professional conduct involving dishonestly, fraud, or receipt or commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence. By using a colleague’s taxi receipt of a higher value, Johnson engages in intentional conduct involving fraud and deceit in the work place that adversely reflects on his integrity.
answerFeedback.4b464d13-ecb9-4774-bdff-b061a02d24ad: Incorrect because Johnson has violated Standard I (D), Misconduct, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.a05f5948-6a61-4335-8bd4-fd03127fd40e: Incorrect because the guidance under Standard I (D), Misconduct, states that personal bankruptcy may not reflect on the integrity or trustworthiness of the person declaring bankruptcy. Declaring personal bankruptcy due to large medical bills for a family member, which does not involve any fraudulent or deceitful business conduct, is not a Standard violation relating to misconduct.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, by submitting the expense claim
C. Yes, by declaring personal bankruptcy

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 06RRJ 31U3
entry.itemBody: Michael Butcher, CFA, has recently joined Patriot Investments (PI) as an investment manager. With information gathered from public sources, Butcher re-creates supporting records from his former firm for investment recommendations at PI. Butcher also reviews client positions and routinely deletes records of the reviews that do not result in a change. Butcher has most likely violated the Standards:

answerFeedback.5a564fda-06d5-4dbd-9bd6-9dba7d070c97: Correct because Standard V (C), Record Retention, states that the retention requirement applies to decisions to buy and sell a security as well as reviews undertaken that do not lead to a change in position.
answerFeedback.83bb07d9-b12c-4e4e-a66e-ab4e5930914f: Incorrect because while Standard V (C), Record Retention, indicates that while failing to retain records of position reviews resulting in no change is a violation, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, re-creating supporting records from public sources is not a violation. The member or candidate must re-create the supporting records at the new firm with information gathered through public sources or directly from the covered company and not from memory or sources obtained at the previous employer.
answerFeedback.fda123e3-83a7-4630-a5b0-644e26d1afb7: Incorrect because Standard V (C), Record Retention, states that the member or candidate must re-create the supporting records at the new firm with information gathered through public sources or directly from the covered company and not from memory or sources obtained at the previous employer.

choices.itemBody: A. only by deleting the reviews that do not result in a change.
B. only by re-creating supporting records for investment recommendations.
C. both by deleting the reviews that do not result in a change and by re-creating supporting records for investment recommendations.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 19UXH 29U3
entry.itemBody: Ming Xu, CFA, is an investment advisor at Topnotch Advisors (TNA). Xu plans to leave TNA and start an independent advisory practice that would compete with TNA. Without notifying TNA of his plans, Xu makes preparations during non-working hours to start his independent practice. Has Xu most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.2a30d5ad-a555-44dc-bcf0-2b5e44666cfa: Correct because Xu has not violated the Standards. According to Standard IV (A) Loyalty, a departing employee is generally free to make arrangements or preparations to go into a competitive business before terminating the relationship with his or her employer as long as such preparations do not breach the employee’s duty of loyalty. There is no evidence to believe that Xu’s action breaches her employer’s duty of loyalty. Therefore, Xu she has not violated the Standard IV (A). Further, according to Standard VI (A) Disclosure of Conflicts, Members and Candidates must make full and fair disclosure of all matters that could reasonably be expected to impair their independence and objectivity or interfere with respective duties to their clients, prospective clients, and employer. Reportable situations include conflicts that would interfere with rendering unbiased investment advice and conflicts that would cause a member or candidate to act not in the employer’s best interest. Xu only makes preparations during non-working hours to start her independent practice. Therefore, Xu has also not violated Standard VI (A).
answerFeedback.3c709bc6-8d6f-4a11-adfd-0e16263e05bc: Incorrect because Xu has not violated Standard IV (A), Loyalty, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.87a97644-fbc1-41c5-8473-d691baf24a03: Incorrect because Xu has not violated Standard VI (A), Disclosure of Conflicts, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to loyalty
C. Yes, the Standard relating to disclosure of conflicts

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00248
entry.itemBody: According to the Standards, members who are supervisors are most likely required to:

answerFeedback.40ee374e-6143-4035-a2d6-ff96878201c6: Correct because according to Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, Members and candidates acting as supervisors must also have in-depth knowledge of the Code and Standards so that they can apply this knowledge in discharging their supervisory responsibilities.
answerFeedback.6874f996-13fc-4efe-a708-5c0550d52144: Incorrect because according to Standard I (A), Knowledge of the Law, CFA Institute encourages members, nonmembers, clients, and the investing public to report violations of the Code and Standards by CFA Institute members or CFA candidates by submitting a complaint in writing to the CFA Institute Professional Conduct Program. Members are encouraged to report violations of the Code and Standard by members to CFA Institute, but it is not mandatory for supervisors.
answerFeedback.ab18d78c-5bbe-4ed5-8be0-6670b1dc51e4: Incorrect because according to Standard IV (C), the conduct that constitutes reasonable supervision in a particular case depends on the number of employees supervised and the work performed by those employees. Members and candidates with oversight responsibilities for large numbers of employees may not be able to personally evaluate the conduct of these employees on a continuing basis. These members and candidates may delegate supervisory duties to subordinates who directly oversee the other employees. Members who are supervisors may delegate supervisory duties and are not required to personally evaluate each employee on a continuing basis.

choices.itemBody: A. have in-depth knowledge of the Standards.
B. personally evaluate the conduct of all of their employees on a continuing basis.
C. report violations of the Standards by any employee under their supervision to CFA Institute.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 12AXA31U1
entry.itemBody: Anna Yeung, CFA, is a research analyst with TL Securities (TLS). TLS does not have a policy on record retention, and applicable law does not require retaining records. Yeung only retains her work records electronically and deletes records older than three years. Are Yeung’s actions consistent with the recommendations for compliance with the Standard relating to record retention?

answerFeedback.3b9abb5d-871a-4f61-94bf-339c543e0b16: Incorrect because according to Standard V (C), Record Retention, records may be maintained either in hard copy or electronic form.
answerFeedback.6a6c62da-e7f9-4c92-85b7-44d30e893415: Correct because according to Standard V (C), Record Retention, in the absence of regulatory guidance or firm policies, CFA Institute recommends maintaining records for at least seven years. Since she deletes records that are older than three years she is not consistent with the Standard relating to record retention.
answerFeedback.c20ca1c5-f000-4649-8687-3c6761a460e4: Incorrect because Standard V (C), Record Retention, in the absence of regulatory guidance or firm policies, CFA Institute recommends maintaining records for at least seven years. Thus, she should have kept the records longer.

choices.itemBody: A. Yes
B. No, because she only retains her work records electronically
C. No, because she deletes her records that are older than three years

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00249
entry.itemBody: Patrick Tam, CFA, is a chemicals industry analyst for an investment firm. The president of Naxos Chemicals (Naxos) asks Tam to provide customized reports on global industry trends in return for free travel and accommodations for the Naxos annual shareholder meeting. To comply with the Standards, Tam is most likely required:

answerFeedback.322149f2-be34-40c6-a381-c8050fc0a50b: Incorrect because Tam is also required to obtain written permission from his employer before accepting the offer from Naxos, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.d589d104-16df-40a2-8446-e736280e1727: Correct because according to Standard VI (A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, the most obvious conflicts of interest, which should always be disclosed, are relationships between an issuer and the member, the candidate, or his or her firm (such as a directorship or consultancy by a member. Although the compensation Tam would receive for the industry reports is relatively meager, there would be a separate relationship with a firm he covers, which must be disclosed. In addition, according to Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, Members and candidates must not accept gifts, benefits, compensation, or consideration that competes with or might reasonably be expected to create a conflict of interest with their employer's interest unless they obtain written consent from all parties involved. Writing special reports for a company the analyst is following would reasonably be construed as creating a conflict of interest with the employer because Tam would be expected to write industry reports for his employer as the chemicals industry analyst.
answerFeedback.fa4c7c92-01de-4ec6-aaa7-40bef854e2d9: Incorrect because Tam is also required to fully disclose arrangement with Naxos to all of the firm's clients, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. only to fully disclose the arrangement with Naxos to all of the firm's clients.
B. only to obtain written permission from his employer before accepting the offer from Naxos.
C. both to fully disclose the arrangement with Naxos to all of the firm's clients and to obtain written permission from his employer before accepting the offer from Naxos.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10211
entry.itemBody:
To be consistent with the Standard relating to record retention, a member should maintain records of which of the following?

  • Item 1: A change in recommendation posted on social media.
  • Item 2: Reviews of materials that do not lead to a change in recommendation.

answerFeedback.18144f30-7727-4c0a-8532-284819865ca9: Incorrect because according to Standard V (C), Record Retention, recommendations posted on social media should be maintained as records, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.9a9489c5-3585-4e79-97b5-02a8626a2325: Incorrect because according to Standard V (C), Record Retention, reviews that do not lead to a change in recommendation also should be maintained as records, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.f57fee85-6f94-41b7-b59d-4585d17977e9: Correct because according to Standard V (C), Record Retention, the nature or format of the information does not remove a member's or candidate's responsibility to maintain a record of information used in his or her analysis or communicated to clients. Examples of nonprint media formats that should be retained include, but are not limited to blog posts and Twitter posts. The retention requirement applies to decisions to buy or sell a security as well as reviews undertaken that do not lead to a change in position.

choices.itemBody: A. Item 1 only
B. Item 2 only
C. Both Item 1 and Item 2

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06361
entry.itemBody: According to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, members should encourage their firms to:

answerFeedback.6121be93-f272-4007-88cd-27577d19d32b: Correct because recommended procedures for compliance with Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, state that once a compliance program is in place, a supervisor should continually educate personnel regarding the compliance procedures.
answerFeedback.6559ad1c-2745-47ff-bc37-f8c91c63f228: Incorrect because recommended procedures for compliance with Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, state that  mingling compliance procedures in the firm's code of ethics goes against the goal of reinforcing the ethical obligations of employees. Thus the recommendation is to keep the firm's code of ethics and its compliance procedures separate rather than to integrate them into one document.
answerFeedback.a06eeac2-fee8-41d8-ab2f-45076de61054: Incorrect because recommended procedures for compliance with Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, state that once a compliance program is in place, a supervisor should incorporate a professional conduct evaluation as part of an employee's performance review. Thus the recommendation is to integrate rather than separate employees' professional conduct evaluations and their performance reviews.

choices.itemBody: A. continually educate personnel regarding all of the firm's compliance procedures.
B. separate employees' professional conduct evaluations from their performance reviews.
C. integrate the firm's compliance procedures into its code of ethics to provide a comprehensive document.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07111
entry.itemBody: In the absence of regulations or firm policies, the Standards recommend retaining investment-related records for a minimum of:

answerFeedback.0efc9289-47bb-4567-85ca-ff60c13430cb: Incorrect because Standard V (C), Record Retention, states that in the absence of regulatory guidance or firm policies, CFA Institute recommends maintaining records for at least seven years, not five years.
answerFeedback.1325b838-945c-45bc-a1f3-13da6d9810df: Incorrect because Standard V (C), Record Retention, states that in the absence of regulatory guidance or firm policies, CFA Institute recommends maintaining records for at least seven years, not ten years.
answerFeedback.32ed1d46-ad75-4607-a05b-088223866290: Correct because Standard V (C), Record Retention, states that in the absence of regulatory guidance or firm policies, CFA Institute recommends maintaining records for at least seven years.

choices.itemBody: A. five years.
B. seven years.
C. ten years.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lin-13
entry.itemBody: A candidate taking the CFA Level II exam develops an analytical model while working as an unpaid intern at a brokerage firm. Before completing her internship, the candidate copies supporting documents used to create the model with an intention to recreate the model at a new firm she expects to join soon. Has the candidate violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.b3bf9fcd-c94e-4e6a-852c-4b154c6dfcf5: Incorrect because the candidate violated the Standard relating to record retention and the Standard relating to loyalty, as described below in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.cf53f35f-1903-4409-af1d-96ef6e57ed96:
Correct because Standard V(C), Record Retention, states that as a general matter, records created as part of a member’s or candidate’s professional activity on behalf of his or her employer are the property of the firm. When a member or candidate leaves a firm to seek other employment, the member or candidate cannot take the property of the firm, including original forms or copies of supporting records of the member’s or candidate’s work, to the new employer without the express consent of the previous employer. The candidate cannot copy the supporting documents without the consent of the current employer. Therefore, the candidate has violated the Standard V(C).

 

In addition, Standard IV(A), Loyalty, states that, even if a candidate does not receive monetary compensation for her services at a firm, she is considered an employee if she receives compensation and benefits in the form of work experience and knowledge. Therefore by copying the supporting document, the candidate violated Standard IV(A) because she misappropriated the firm's property without permission.
answerFeedback.fff05244-9a96-43cc-b8ae-d4043cc45931: Incorrect because the candidate violated the Standard relating to record retention and the Standard relating to loyalty, as described below in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to record retention only
C. Yes, the Standard relating to record retention and the Standard relating to loyalty

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Irvin-10
entry.itemBody: Disclosures about the use of leverage, sector or industry risk, and security-specific risk are most likely included in the Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.1607280f-fcf5-432e-b0c1-bd3035eed15b: Incorrect because discussions about leverage, sector or industry risk, and security-specific risk are not included in the guidance for Standard I (B), Independence and Objectivity, which states that Members must use reasonable care and judgment to achieve and maintain independence and objectivity in their professional activities. Members and Candidates must not offer, solicit, or accept any gift, benefit, compensation, or consideration that reasonably could be expected to compromise their own or another’s independence and objectivity.
answerFeedback.a6b52634-e5ac-441d-be03-bf1f78d8e5f9: Correct because discussions about leverage, sector or industry risk, and security-specific risk are included in the guidance for Standard V (B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients. This Standard states that Members must outline to clients and prospective clients significant risks and limitations of the analysis contained in their investment products or recommendations. This includes but is not limited to the use of leverage, sector or industry risk, and security-specific risk. The type and nature of significant risks will depend on the investment process that members are following and on the personal circumstances of the client. In general, the use of leverage constitutes a significant risk and should be disclosed.
answerFeedback.d423b6c8-60c6-4197-9d56-05eae51c2bbc: Incorrect because discussions about leverage, sector or industry risk, and security-specific risk are not included in the guidance for Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, which requires that Members must make reasonable efforts to ensure that anyone subject to their supervision or authority complies with applicable laws, rules, regulations, and the Code and Standards.

choices.itemBody: A. independence and objectivity.
B. responsibilities of supervisors.
C. communication with clients and prospective clients.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04086
entry.itemBody: Agnes Dupy, CFA, manages discretionary accounts at a large brokerage firm. She finds a suitable set of the firm's proprietary equity mutual funds for one of her clients. Dupy's firm is awarding a special quarterly bonus to managers who use one of the highest-fee funds on the list of suitable funds, so she invests in that fund for her client without contacting the client. Dupy has most likely violated the Standard(s) relating:

answerFeedback.43af78ee-96e2-4e45-b0e7-ebf2aa2443dc: Incorrect because Dupy did not violate Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, as she did not take advantage of her position to the detriment of clients. She violated only Standard VI (A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, by not disclosing the special bonus.
answerFeedback.8dca33b5-a23a-4523-93cf-28296cd04f64: Correct because Standard VI (A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, states that the Standard protects investors and employers by requiring members and candidates to fully disclose to clients, potential clients, and employers all actual and potential conflicts of interest. Dupy violated the standard by not disclosing the special bonus for the chosen fund.
answerFeedback.ee711921-fffb-4e22-b3c1-20f25826c79a: Incorrect because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, addresses fair dealing of securities allocations, investments and trades among a CFA charterholder's clients as well as seeking to ensure that the charterholder does not take advantage of their position in the industry to the detriment of clients in terms of allocations of trades or initial public offerings. There is no indication in this scenario that Dupy has favored another client or herself in allocating trades.

choices.itemBody: A. only to fair dealing.
B. only to avoid or disclose conflicts.
C. both to fair dealing and to avoid or disclose conflicts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03661
entry.itemBody: Which of the following examples is most likely a violation of the Standards? A member who is a supervisor:

answerFeedback.57c9597a-b65f-4b05-934f-7ad335e6d9d4: Incorrect because according to Standard IV (C), if a member has adopted reasonable procedures and taken steps to institute an effective compliance program, then the member may not be in violation of Standard IV(C) if he or she does not detect violations that occur despite these efforts.
answerFeedback.a80cb3b7-79b1-49f4-90e8-ff06932b2309: Incorrect because according to Standard IV (C), members may delegate supervisory duties to subordinates who directly oversee the other employees. A supervisor, depending on the circumstances, may not be able to personally monitor all his subordinates. In such cases, he may delegate his supervisory duty to subordinates who directly oversee other employees without violating the Standard.
answerFeedback.b1ac3769-ff43-47a1-bd1f-0ae7029b907e: Correct because according to Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, once a supervisor learns that an employee has violated or may have violated the law or the Code and Standards, the supervisor must promptly initiate an assessment to determine the extent of the wrongdoing. Relying on an employee's statements about the extent of the violation or assurances that the wrongdoing will not reoccur is not enough. A supervisor should take steps to ensure that the violation will not be repeated. A supervisor must make sure that such violation will not reoccur.

choices.itemBody: A. delegates supervisory duties to subordinates who oversee other employees.
B. relies on an employee's statement that previous wrongdoing will not reoccur and takes no additional steps.
C. fails to detect all violations, although the member has taken reasonable steps to implement an effective compliance program.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06007
entry.itemBody: A candidate posts questions from the most recent CFA exam in an online forum. This action is a violation of the Standard(s) relating:

answerFeedback.3dd14f5d-eb72-421e-92e0-4e2f1782f4e5: Correct because Standard VII(A), Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, states CFA Institute program rules, regulations, and policies prohibit candidates from disclosing confidential material gained during the exam process. Examples of information that cannot be disclosed by candidates sitting for an exam include but are not limited to specific details of questions appearing on the exam.
answerFeedback.645c3c5d-90ef-4fcd-ac4f-80c30db109a6: Incorrect because only Standard VII(A), Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, requires the member to keep information from the exam process confidential, as stated in the rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.d53644ca-5b4e-46b9-9d9b-0bd62b040454: Incorrect because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. This Standard does not apply to the confidentiality of the CFA exam.

choices.itemBody: A. to preservation of confidentiality only.
B. to conduct as participants in CFA Institute programs only.
C. both to preservation of confidentiality and to conduct as participants in CFA Institute programs.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lee-09
entry.itemBody: According to the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, a member who cannot discharge supervisory responsibilities due to his firm’s inadequate compliance system should:

answerFeedback.7ea80c2f-840f-446e-ba3c-d4a3628e1aa5: Incorrect because Standard IV(C), responsibilities of supervisors, does not require a member to report his firm’s inadequate compliance system to the CFA Institute.
answerFeedback.9747d8d6-ef8e-440b-8bea-04c315778d5a: Incorrect because Standard IV(C), responsibilities of supervisors, does not require a member to report his firm’s inadequate compliance system to the CFA Institute. In particular, the CFA Institute requires that CFA Institute members and candidates enrolled in the CFA Program are required to comply with the Code and Standards.
answerFeedback.bf9716de-bf17-4b8f-bfad-3808c82fa574: Correct because according to Standard IV(C), responsibilities of supervisors, if the member or candidate clearly cannot discharge supervisory responsibilities because of the absence of a compliance system or because of an inadequate compliance system, the member or candidate should decline in writing to accept supervisory responsibility until the firm adopts reasonable procedures to allow adequate exercise of supervisory responsibility.

choices.itemBody: A. decline in writing to accept supervisory responsibility only.
B. report the inadequate compliance system to the CFA Institute only.
C. both decline in writing to accept supervisory responsibility and report the inadequate compliance system to the CFA Institute.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 06UXH 22U3
entry.itemBody: Which of the following Standards states that members must not commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence? The Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.64ba4683-0a04-4298-860f-9a628752b697: Correct because according to Standard I (D), Misconduct, Members and Candidates must not engage in any professional conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, or deceit or commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence.
answerFeedback.882b379d-eaa2-4d70-aaaf-c852378184af: Incorrect because according to Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, Members and Candidates have a duty of loyalty to their clients and must act with reasonable care and exercise prudent judgment. Members and Candidates must act for the benefit of their clients and place their clients’ interests before their employer’s or their own interests. Standard III (A) does not address members’ responsibility to not commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence.
answerFeedback.eab8eeaf-a445-4137-a444-b1d04acd1596: Incorrect because according to Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, Members and Candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment actions, or engaging in other professional activities. Standard III (B) does not address members’ responsibility to not commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence.

choices.itemBody: A. fair dealing
B. misconduct
C. loyalty, prudence, and care

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02777
entry.itemBody: Anna Schulz, CFA, is a securities analyst. When she joined her firm, Schulz's manager, Zhang Feng, CFA, informed her only that “the CFA Institute Code and Standards pretty much cover the company's compliance rules.” In her personal account, Schulz holds a large position in a company that she recommends for purchase to clients. Schulz does not report this holding to her firm or clients. The Standards were most likely violated:

answerFeedback.28256b71-e808-45b0-8549-b1ceb272dfa2: Correct because according to Standard IV (C), Responsibilities of Supervisors, Members and Candidates must promote actions by all employees under their supervision and authority to comply with applicable laws, rules, regulations, and firm policies and the Code and Standards. At a minimum, Standard IV(C) requires that members and candidates with supervisory responsibility make reasonable efforts to prevent and detect violations by ensuring the establishment of effective compliance systems. To be effective supervisors, members and candidates should implement education and training programs on a recurring or regular basis for employees under their supervision. Such programs will assist the employees with meeting their professional obligations to practice in an ethical manner within the applicable legal system. Therefore, by not thoroughly explaining to Schulz or training Schulz in requirements for compliance with applicable laws, rules, regulations, and firm policies, and by not employing/ implementing an effective compliance system, Zhang violated this Standard. In addition, Schulz violated Standard VI (A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, which protects investors and employers by requiring members and candidates to fully disclose to clients, potential clients, and employers all actual and potential conflicts of interest. Also, sell-side members and candidates must disclose any materially beneficial ownership interest in a security or other investment that the member or candidate is recommending. By not disclosing that Schulz holds a large position in a company that she recommends for purchase to clients, Schulz is in violation of Standard VI (A)
answerFeedback.367c21fd-bf2a-4ab8-a615-9f2b274a1eff: Incorrect because both Zhang and Schulz violated the Standards, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.46aa7757-aa19-444e-ae0f-e5a78c05dbbe: Incorrect because both Zhang and Schulz violated the Standards, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. only by Zhang.
B. only by Schulz.
C. both by Zhang and by Schulz.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03540
entry.itemBody: Rayan Tengku, CFA, manages an equity fund. When talking to potential investors, Tengku presents the fund's average historical performance as the minimum performance investors can expect over the next year. After releasing the most recent quarterly fund report, Tengku finds an error in the report. He immediately sends the corrected report to all clients by e-mail and then calls only those clients who pay for premium services to discuss the report. Tengku has most likely violated the Standard(s) relating:

answerFeedback.59736c43-a4fd-4458-b7eb-63bce3eddd32: Incorrect because according to Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, the term ‘fairly' implies that the member or candidate must take care not to discriminate against any clients when disseminating investment recommendations or taking investment action. Standard III(B) does not state ‘equally' because members and candidates could not possibly reach all clients at exactly the same time. In addition, members and candidates may provide more personal, specialized, or in-depth service to clients who are willing to pay for premium services through higher management fees or higher levels of brokerage. Therefore, Tengku has not violated Standard III (B) by additionally calling premium clients who pay higher fees since he had already distributed the corrected report to all clients by e-mail before calling his premium clients.
answerFeedback.919948ad-e841-4cbe-ba5a-0dadf151f62d: Incorrect because Tengku has only violated Standard III (D) and not Standard III (B), as described above.
answerFeedback.9aad6071-0f4f-4a85-89cd-87905783383b: Correct because Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, prohibits misrepresentations of past performance or reasonably expected performance. A member or candidate must give a fair and complete presentation of performance information. Furthermore, members and candidates should not state or imply that clients will obtain or benefit from a rate of return that was generated in the past. Therefore, by stating that the fund's average historic performance is representative of investors' minimum future performance, Tengku has violated Standard III (D).

choices.itemBody: A. only to fair dealing.
B. only to performance presentation.
C. both to fair dealing and to performance presentation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08353
entry.itemBody: Emilio Torro, CFA, owns a small investment firm. He sends a brochure to potential clients which states: “As a CFA charterholder, Emilio Torro will deliver better investment performance compared to the competition. Over the past 6 years, Torro has beaten the market in every single year and will continue to do so in the future.” Torro has most likely violated the Standard(s) relating to:

answerFeedback.05fa725d-69c9-405f-b15c-b29f1735050e: Incorrect because, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer, Torro has violated both Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, as well as Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program.
answerFeedback.11bdb3b4-b2fd-4cba-9afc-966b0b8d5142: Incorrect because, as described in the Response Rationale for the correct answer, Torro has violated both Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, as well as Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program.
answerFeedback.29d793c6-e542-4a83-8cff-561eeb73ec18:
Correct because according to Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, members and candidates should not state or imply that clients will obtain or benefit from a rate of return that was generated in the past. This standard also prohibits misrepresentations of past performance or reasonably expected performance. By stating "Over the past 6 years, Torro has beaten the market in every single year and will continue to do so in the future", Torro has violated Standard III (D) because he misrepresents reasonably expected performance.  

According to Standard VII (B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program, statements that overstate the competency of an individual or imply, either directly or indirectly, that superior performance can be expected from someone with the CFA designation are not allowed under the standard. Therefore, by stating, “As a CFA charterholder, Emilio Torro will deliver better investment performance compared to the competition", Torro has violated Standard VII (B) because he states that superior performance can be expected from someone with the CFA designation. Therefore, Torro has violated both the Standard relating to performance presentation and the Standard relating to reference to the CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program.

choices.itemBody: A. performance presentation only.
B. reference to the CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program only.
C. both performance presentation and reference to the CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01559
entry.itemBody: Herman Standish, CFA, is a top analyst in the semiconductor industry. Standish issues a report on International Chips (IC) to clients of his firm that highlights a change in his recommendation from “hold” to “strong buy.” He writes in the report: “Just as it has in the past two years, IC will double its earnings and its dividend.” After three business days, Standish releases the report to the business press. Which of the following Standards has Standish most likely violated?

answerFeedback.3c8acf1e-50cd-449e-a2b2-bf22500764cd: Incorrect because Standish has not violated Standard II (A), Material Nonpublic Information.
answerFeedback.49d122e7-6522-4d2b-80c1-fc8729e15f43: Incorrect because Standish has not violated Standard II (A), Material Nonpublic Information, which states that simply because the public in general would find the conclusions material does not require that the analyst make his or her work public. Therefore, Standish has not violated this Standard by distributing his report to his clients before making it public.
answerFeedback.84ee57e9-8dd9-4eca-9a04-613ac9989900: Correct because Standard V (B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, requires that opinion be separated from fact. Violations often occur when reports fail to separate the past from the future by not indicating that earnings estimates, changes in the outlook for dividends, or future market price information are opinions subject to future circumstances. Standish violated the Standard by writing IC will double its earnings and its dividend in his report.

choices.itemBody: A. Only the Standard relating to material nonpublic information
B. Only the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients
C. Both the Standard relating to material nonpublic information and the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-McCormick-01
entry.itemBody: Member violations of the Standard relating to misconduct must involve a(n):

answerFeedback.0d6744b8-6fb0-4d56-af5a-3c034305f47f: Incorrect because Standard I (D), Misconduct, states that conduct that damages trustworthiness or competence may include behavior that, although not illegal, nevertheless negatively affects a member’s or candidate’s ability to perform his or her responsibilities. Though violations of Standard I (D) often involve violations of other Standards, Standard I (D) does not require that another Standard be violated for this Standard to apply.
answerFeedback.22703265-abf3-499e-a528-b9e501993fc7: Incorrect because Standard I (D), Misconduct, states that conduct that damages trustworthiness or competence may include behavior that, although not illegal, nevertheless negatively affects a member’s or candidate’s ability to perform his or her responsibilities. Thus, a member can violate the Standard without committing an illegal act.
answerFeedback.a3ec4372-bf77-47e3-98a9-3d88f037d6ce: Correct because Standard I (D), Misconduct, states that Members and Candidates must not engage in any professional conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, or deceit or commit any act that reflects adversely on their professional reputation, integrity, or competence.

choices.itemBody: A. illegal act.
B. violation of one of the other Standards.
C. act that reflects adversely on the member's professional reputation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Agarwal-02
entry.itemBody: Hemant Sampath, CFA, is a wealth manager. He is contacted by a charity requesting donations. Sampath refuses to share information about existing clients to protect client confidentiality. While communicating with existing clients, Sampath shares contact details of the charity. He also shares contact details of former clients with the charity. Has Sampath violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.1fdbd99e-95e7-487a-b939-2f8c47bb35ac: Incorrect because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. Sampath breaches Standard III(E) by sharing contact details of former clients with the charity.
answerFeedback.af41cb33-25c6-4f1f-9506-562dec32a4ea: Incorrect because Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, entails communication information related to investments and the investment process. Sharing contact details of a charity with existing clients is not a violation of Standard V(B).
answerFeedback.f04d8fd7-fa39-435c-94b0-fdea754ff58c: Correct because Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, requires that members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. Sampath breaches Standard III(E) by sharing contact details of former clients with the charity.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to preservation of confidentiality
C. Yes, the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Kennan-02
entry.itemBody: CFA Institute encourages members to report other members' violations of the Code and Standards in writing to the CFA Institute:

answerFeedback.091961a2-8c07-44d4-9dc4-84928bcc0645: Incorrect because the CFA Institute encourages members to report violations to the Professional Conduct Program, not the Board of Governors.
answerFeedback.26ee7fb4-b515-4db7-a574-2aa42268e8c4: Correct because CFA Institute encourages members, nonmembers, clients, and the investing public to report violations of the Code and Standards by CFA Institute members or CFA candidates by submitting a complaint in writing to the CFA Institute Professional Conduct Program.
answerFeedback.45045dc6-b480-4524-830b-d1938c166bc9: Incorrect because the CFA Institute encourages members to report violations to the Professional Conduct Program, not the Disciplinary Review Committee.

choices.itemBody: A. Board of Governors.
B. Professional Conduct Program.
C. Disciplinary Review Committee.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Lamba-04
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following is among the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to preservation of confidentiality?

• Procedure 1: Convey to clients that not all firm-sponsored resources may be appropriate for confidential communications.

• Procedure 2: Ensure that firm-supported communications follow practices designed to prevent the accidental distribution of confidential information.

answerFeedback.2825d164-5d70-48cc-963e-2f070bbb8a34: Correct because according to Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, members and candidates should be diligent in discussing with clients the appropriate methods for providing confidential information. It is important to convey to clients that not all firm-sponsored resources may be appropriate for such communications. So, Procedure 1 is correct. The standard also states that members and candidates need to understand and follow their firm’s electronic information communication and storage procedures. If the firm does not have procedures in place, members and candidates should encourage the development of procedures that appropriately reflect the firm’s size and business operations. So, Procedure 2 is also correct.
answerFeedback.5aecf457-0be8-4009-b011-a944dff952f6: Incorrect because, as described below in the Response Rationale to the correct answer, both Procedure 1 and Procedure 2 comply with Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality.
answerFeedback.7045109b-f625-44cc-89b1-48023670deba: Incorrect because, as described below in the Response Rationale to the correct answer, both Procedure 1 and Procedure 2 comply with Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality.

choices.itemBody: A. Only Procedure 1
B. Only Procedure 2
C. Both Procedure 1 and Procedure 2

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07388
entry.itemBody: A member has a client who pays higher fees for premium services. The Standards most likely allow the member to provide that client with:

answerFeedback.214800db-85fe-4751-a026-d07e79dd1e44: Incorrect because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, addresses the manner in which investment recommendations or changes in prior recommendations are disseminated to clients. Each member or candidate is obligated to ensure that information is disseminated in such a manner that all clients have a fair opportunity to act on every recommendation. Further, members and candidates may differentiate their services to clients, but different levels of service must not disadvantage or negatively affect clients. Therefore, a member is not permitted to provide earlier access to investment recommendations and rating changes to a client who pays higher fees for premium services.
answerFeedback.48691084-f9be-44d1-af37-d142fe31bb70: Correct because according to Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, members and candidates may provide more personal, specialized, or in-depth service to clients who are willing to pay for premium services through higher management fees or higher levels of brokerage. Members and candidates may differentiate their services to clients, but different levels of service must not disadvantage or negatively affect clients. Therefore, a member is permitted to provide direct access to research analysts to discuss published investment ratings in greater detail for a client who pays higher fees for premium services.
answerFeedback.b19e7fe4-a26a-41c2-9f27-2178e0fecbe3: Incorrect because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, requires that members or candidates treat all clients fairly in light of their investment objectives and circumstances. For example, when making investments in new offerings or in secondary financings, members and candidates should distribute the issues to all customers for whom the investments are appropriate in a manner consistent with the policies of the firm for allocating blocks of stock. If the issue is oversubscribed, then the issue should be prorated to all subscribers. Therefore, a member is not permitted to provide larger allocations of oversubscribed IPOs to a client who pays higher fees for premium services.

choices.itemBody: A. larger allocations of oversubscribed IPOs.
B. earlier access to investment recommendations and rating changes.
C. direct access to research analysts to discuss published investment ratings in greater detail.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04441
entry.itemBody: Jong Byun, CFA, is a broker who recommends various investments to his clients, but is not legally charged with a fiduciary responsibility. Byun finds two similar and appropriate mutual funds. One of the funds has a higher fee-sharing arrangement with the broker so he recommends that fund to his clients over the fund with lower fees. Has Byun most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.0a4ec3f5-8a8b-41f0-ba6f-115b17596574: Correct because according to Standard III (A) Loyalty, Prudence and Care, members and Candidates must act for the benefit of their clients and place their clients' interests before their employer's or their own interest. By recommending the fund with the higher fee-sharing when another lower-fee alternative is available, Byun is putting his own interests before those of his clients. Even though he does not have a legal fiduciary requirement, Byun, as a member and has the responsibility to put his clients' needs before his own.
answerFeedback.8dc661a2-eff1-4d84-99e1-953151111a74: Incorrect because Standard III (C), Suitability, requires that members and candidates who are in an investment advisory relationship with clients consider carefully the needs, circumstances, and objectives of the clients when determining the appropriateness and suitability of a given investment or course of investment action. There is no indication that the fund is not suitable for the clients, only that a similar lower-fee alternative is available and not being recommended.
answerFeedback.e7a21613-42d3-4882-9192-f21086966036: Incorrect because Byun violated Standard III (A), as described in the justification for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to suitability
C. Yes, the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09985
entry.itemBody: Maria Estefan, CFA, recently founded Inversiones Unidas (IU). Estefan has a 5-year fund management track record as part of a team with her previous firm, Alto Investments (AI). Estefan advertises her past 5-year track record as her performance at IU without reference to AI or her role on the team at AI. Estefan most likely violates the Standards:

answerFeedback.064bc85e-b500-4081-b65f-21700dae96c8: Incorrect because Estefan has violated Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, not only because she advertised her performance without reference to her role on the team at AI but also because she advertised her performance without reference to AI.
answerFeedback.079a8c3e-ca7c-4793-b28d-dad72099fa18: Incorrect because Estefan has violated Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, not only because she advertised her performance without reference to AI but also because she advertising her performance without reference to her role on the team at AI.
answerFeedback.787aa4f7-9471-44ad-b29e-89c1638b12b9: Correct because according to Standard III (D), Performance Presentation, when communicating investment performance information, members and candidates must make reasonable efforts to ensure that it is fair, accurate, and complete. Further, as a general matter, this standard does not prohibit showing past performance of funds managed at a prior firm as part of a performance track record as long as showing that record is accompanied by appropriate disclosures about where the performance took place and the person's specific role in achieving that performance. So, Estefan is permitted to advertise her past five-year track record with AI provided she makes adequate disclosures in the advertisement relating to the IU's performance presentation. Therefore, Estefan has violated Standard III (D) because she advertised her performance without reference to AI and also failed to make reference to her role on the team at AI.

choices.itemBody: A. only by advertising her performance without reference to AI.
B. only by advertising her performance without reference to her role on the team at AI.
C. both by advertising her performance without reference to AI and by advertising her performance without reference to her role on the team at AI.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02220
entry.itemBody: Jan Ho, CFA, is an advisor who manages portfolios for endowment funds that share a similar goal of conservative growth. He has thoroughly researched and recommended the purchase of a thinly-traded stock for his clients' portfolios. To execute the trades, Ho follows his policy of prioritizing purchases for his largest clients first. Ho has most likely violated the Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.42848fe8-a58a-4bf5-b859-42b50fcb361d: Correct because Standard III(B), Fair Dealing,  requires members and candidates to treat all clients fairly when disseminating investment recommendations or making material changes to prior investment recommendations or when taking investment action with regard to general purchases, new issues, or secondary offerings. Further, the term “fairly” implies that the member or candidate must take care not to discriminate against any clients when disseminating investment recommendations or taking investment action. Therefore, Ho cannot discriminate between his largest clients and other clients by prioritizing trades for the former group first. By doing do, Ho has violated Standard III(B).
answerFeedback.a9d3a556-9f27-4099-894e-0b22881013e6: Incorrect because Standard III(C), Suitability,  requires that members and candidates who are in an investment advisory relationship with clients consider carefully the needs, circumstances, and objectives of the clients when determining the appropriateness and suitability of a given investment or course of investment action. Ho's clients share a similar goal of conservative growth. So, if the stock is appropriate for one client, it is likely appropriate for all other clients. Moreover, there is no reason to believe that the investment is not suitable for Ho's clients. Therefore, Ho has not violated Standard III(C).
answerFeedback.d267ef17-3111-4a9b-ae57-ffd56b514c73: Incorrect because Standard VI(B), Priority of Transactions, states: Standard VI(B) reinforces the responsibility of members and candidates to give the interests of their clients and employers priority over their personal financial interests. The Standard does not relate to how members should prioritize trades among their clients. Moreover, there is no reason to believe that Ho placed his personal financial interests above that of his clients and employer. Therefore, Ho has not violated Standard VI(B).

choices.itemBody: A. suitability.
B. fair dealing.
C. priority of transactions.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05681
entry.itemBody: Alicia Garcia, CFA, is a broker. Her firm's analyst changes a prior "Buy" recommendation on Ajax Data (AD) to "Sell" and Garcia publishes the recommendation change on the firm's website. Later that day, one of Garcia's clients contacts her with an order directing Garcia to buy shares of AD for the client's non-discretionary account. According to the Standard relating to fair dealing, Garcia should:

answerFeedback.2598cae5-c02a-4653-b054-9d2b5183639c: Incorrect because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, does not state that Garcia should refuse the order. Rather, the Standard states that Garcia should advise the client of the change before accepting the order, as explained in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.2dba72c8-6b67-4501-ae62-9fc7830f177f: Incorrect because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, states that Garcia should advise the client of the changed recommendation before accepting the order, as explained in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.5e456272-fd82-4e6f-ac37-bdf6e7822fd4: Correct because Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, addresses the manner in which investment recommendations or changes in prior recommendations are disseminated to clients. Clients who do not know that the member or candidate has changed a recommendation and who, therefore, place orders contrary to a current recommendation should be advised of the changed recommendation before the order is accepted. Therefore, Garcia should advise the client of the recommendation change before accepting the order.

choices.itemBody: A. refuse to execute the order.
B. advise the client of the recommendation change before accepting the order.
C. accept and immediately execute the order because the client's account is non-discretionary.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08038
entry.itemBody: Ria Preston, CFA, works for an investment firm. Her brother is a fee-paying client of the firm. Preston allocates shares in an oversubscribed IPO that she considers suitable for all of her firm's clients. To avoid potential conflicts of interest, Preston does not allocate shares from the IPO to herself or to her brother. Has Preston most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.3ab49370-7568-4106-9438-f8d689f0fc9c: Incorrect because Preston has violated Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, by not allocating shares to her brother's account, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.3d768bec-31b0-4d6c-b229-4682128ec242: Correct because according to Standard III (B), Fair Dealing, if the issue is oversubscribed, members and candidates should forgo any sales to themselves or their immediate families in order to free up additional shares for clients. If the investment professional's family-member accounts are managed similarly to the accounts of other clients of the firm, however, the family-member accounts should not be excluded from buying such shares. In addition, Standard III (B) requires members and candidates to treat all clients fairly when disseminating investment recommendations or making material changes to prior investment recommendations or when taking investment action with regard to general purchases, new issues, or secondary offerings. As a fee-paying client, Preston's brother's account must be treated like as any other client account and allocated shares accordingly. Therefore, Preston has violated Standard III (B) because she failed to allocate shares to her brother's account.
answerFeedback.b335a638-3ea0-494f-91ad-6947ea6ab911: Incorrect because according to Standard V (A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, members and candidates must exercise diligence, independence, and thoroughness in analyzing investments, making investment recommendations, and taking investment actions. Standard V (A) does not discuss about how members must treat their clients. Also, there is no evidence to suggest that Preston lacked diligence and reasonable basis while arriving at the decision to invest in the IPO. Therefore, Preston has not violated Standard V (A).

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to fair dealing
C. Yes, the Standard relating to diligence and reasonable basis

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09460
entry.itemBody: Judy Naden, CFA, is an analyst covering the aerospace sector. Naden's recommendations often impact stock prices within the sector. Naden finalizes an investment recommendation on a company using published financial data and nonmaterial, nonpublic information gathered from industry experts and competitors. She distributes the report only to her firm's clients by email. Her firm's clients trade on this information before her report is made available to the general public a few days later. Has Naden most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.044af3c4-4753-42d2-9cea-3f48ea11a2d9: Incorrect because according to Standard II (A), Material Nonpublic Information, Naden is permitted to use the information gathered from industry experts and competitors in her report. Therefore, Naden has not violated Standard II (A), as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.6633c675-237c-4a85-b875-bfba94c7baee: Correct because according to Standard II (A), Material Nonpublic Information, a financial analyst gathers and interprets large quantities of information from many sources. The analyst may use significant conclusions derived from the analysis of public and nonmaterial nonpublic information as the basis for investment recommendations and decisions even if those conclusions would have been material inside information had they been communicated directly to the analyst by a company. Under the “mosaic theory,” financial analysts are free to act on this collection, or mosaic, of information without risking violation. Therefore, Naden is permitted to use published financial data and nonmaterial, nonpublic information gathered from industry experts and competitor to arrive at his investment recommendation. Further, Standard II (A) states, when a particularly well-known or respected analyst issues a report or makes changes to his or her recommendation, that information alone may have an effect on the market and thus may be considered material. Theoretically, under Standard II(A), such a report would have to be made public at the time it was distributed to clients. The analyst is not a company insider, however, and does not have access to inside information. In addition, simply because the public in general would find the conclusions material does not require that the analyst make his or her work public. So, Naden is not required to make her recommendation available to her clients and the public at the same time. Therefore, Naden has not violated Standard II (A) either by using the information gathered from industry experts and competitors in her report or by failing to make her recommendation available to her clients and the public at the same time.
answerFeedback.7ea37730-0077-43e1-8476-e30e9ff48de4: Incorrect because according to Standard II (A), Material Nonpublic Information, Naden is not required to make her recommendation available to her clients and the public at the same time, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, by using the information gathered from industry experts and competitors in her report
C. Yes, by failing to make her recommendation available to her firm's clients and the public at the same time

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01159
entry.itemBody: According to the guidance provided by the Code and Standards, which of the following is not a recommended procedure for compliance with the Standard relating to material nonpublic information?

answerFeedback.c3bc8d5e-95a1-4d6d-9615-2796c54cd53f: Correct because this is not a recommended procedure for compliance with Standard II (A), Material Non-Public Information. The recommended procedure is in fact the opposite, the member should make reasonable efforts to achieve public dissemination of the information.
answerFeedback.c880a9fa-25ed-45b4-9f87-916e46fddcb3: Incorrect because according to Standard II (A), a recommended procedure for compliance is to adopt disclosure procedures. Members and candidates should encourage their firms to develop and follow disclosure policies designed to ensure that information is disseminated to the marketplace in an equitable manner.
answerFeedback.ef0a7533-e74d-4b6f-8758-87f268cf90c1: Incorrect because according to Standard II (A), a recommended procedure for compliance is physical separation of departments. Firms should consider the physical separation of departments and files to prevent the communication of sensitive information that should not be shared. For example, the investment banking and corporate finance areas of a brokerage firm should be separated from the sales and research departments, and a bank's commercial lending department should be segregated from its trust and research departments.

choices.itemBody: A. Physical separation of departments
B. Adopt disclosure procedures for material nonpublic information
C. Avoid public dissemination of material nonpublic information received

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07104
entry.itemBody: A member works for an investment firm and implements policies to ensure that the use of soft dollars benefits clients. These policies are most likely put in place to comply with the Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.190b3c8e-d22d-4b3c-a554-d902ade712bc: Incorrect because Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, states the responsibility of members and candidates to inform their employer, clients, and prospective clients of any benefit received for referrals of customers and clients. Standard VI (C) does not discuss members' responsibility relating to soft dollars or soft commissions.
answerFeedback.5f64965c-2b8f-40e6-8ea8-b7bdb3e336c9: Correct because, according to Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, conflicts may arise when an investment manager uses client brokerage to purchase research services, a practice commonly called 'soft dollars' or 'soft commissions.' A member or candidate who pays a higher brokerage commission than he or she would normally pay to allow for the purchase of goods or services, without corresponding benefit to the client, violates the duty of loyalty to the client. Therefore, a member who implements policies to ensure that the use of soft dollars benefits clients complies with the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care.
answerFeedback.adc76e67-e5da-4afc-8364-a4044f4aa332: Incorrect because Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, requires members and candidates to obtain permission from their employer before accepting compensation or other benefits from third parties for the services rendered to the employer or for any services that might create a conflict with their employer's interest. Standard IV (B) does not discuss members' responsibility relating to soft dollars or soft commissions.

choices.itemBody: A. referral fees.
B. loyalty, prudence, and care.
C. additional compensation arrangements.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 09HFJ
entry.itemBody: According to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care, a member who has control of client assets should:

answerFeedback.29ea0bbf-d11a-44bd-9792-c738a463fdd0: Correct because according to recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, a member should submit to each client, at least quarterly, an itemized statement showing the funds and securities in the custody or possession of the member or candidate plus all debits, credits, and transactions that occurred during the period.
answerFeedback.60531f81-a594-48d2-9f5e-1099460f7d5a: Incorrect because according to recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, a member should separate the client’s assets from any other party’s assets, including the member’s or candidate’s own assets. Therefore, the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (A) are to separate client assets from other parties’ assets, not to combine them.
answerFeedback.ae21a1d6-b861-4fe7-97b3-6ba4199c6072: Incorrect because according to recommended procedures for compliance with Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, in most cases, members and candidates should determine who is authorized to vote shares and vote proxies in the best interests of the clients and ultimate beneficiaries. It is not a recommended procedure for members to vote proxies in the best interests of their firm.

choices.itemBody: A. vote proxies in the best interests of her firm.
B. submit quarterly itemized account statements to her clients.
C. combine her clients’ assets with other parties’ assets to reduce administrative costs.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Ethics 12EWL
entry.itemBody: Mark Joy, CFA, manages the pension fund for Bank Ltd. (BL). Joy believes that BL stock is overvalued. BL’s CEO requests Joy purchase BL stock for BL’s pension fund to help prevent a hostile takeover of BL. Joy complies and his purchase of BL stock for the pension fund helps prevent the takeover. Subsequently, BL’s stock price increases, which also increases the value of BL’s pension fund. Has Joy most likely violated the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care?

answerFeedback.84ee0c0b-ed5b-49f8-8130-5978f6cfbed6: Incorrect because Joy would not be permitted to purchase the stock given his duty is owed to the Bank pension fund beneficiaries. However, the subsequent price increase does not change the fact that it is a violation.
answerFeedback.8abc7709-fd54-4393-bc7a-4c93cda60c6f: Correct because Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, states that members have a duty of loyalty to their clients. When the manager is responsible for the portfolios of pension plans, the client is not the person or entity who hires the manager but, rather, the beneficiaries of the plan or trust. The duty of loyalty is owed to the ultimate beneficiaries. Joy should not have complied with the CEO’s request to buy the stock when he believes the stock is overvalued, because his duty is not owed to BL nor to the CEO. His duty is owed to the BL pension fund beneficiaries. Therefore, Joy would not be permitted to purchase the stock, and this is the correct answer.
answerFeedback.ebeda541-4fc8-4141-bd0e-dff9f683006f: Incorrect because Joy would not be permitted to purchase the stock given his duty is owed to the Bank pension fund beneficiaries, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, because BL stock subsequently increased
C. Yes, because Joy complies with the CEO’s request

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Ethics-Augulyte-12
entry.itemBody: According to the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care, a member who is hired to manage an equity mutual fund:

answerFeedback.059357be-4b21-4f03-b106-0f26a948bf6c: Correct because according to the guidance for Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence and Care: Members and candidates managing a fund to an index or an expected mandate owe the duty of loyalty, prudence, and care to invest in a manner consistent with the stated mandate.
answerFeedback.a1d0fada-36ce-411a-9b1d-b7bf5156aac0: Incorrect because according to Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, in the context of an investment manager managing the personal assets of an individual, the client is easily identified. When the manager is responsible for the portfolios of pension plans or trusts, however, the client is not the person or entity who hires the manager but, rather, the beneficiaries of the plan or trust. The duty of loyalty is owed to the ultimate beneficiaries. Members and candidates managing a fund to an index or an expected mandate owe the duty of loyalty, prudence, and care to invest in a manner consistent with the stated mandate. Thus, the duty is not owed to the firm who hired the manager but to fund beneficiaries.
answerFeedback.ed66a030-07b5-4da2-954c-8e351833d899: Incorrect because according to Standard III (A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, a cost–benefit analysis may show that voting all proxies may not benefit the client, so voting proxies may not be necessary in all instances.

choices.itemBody: A. is required to vote proxies in all instances.
B. owes the duty of loyalty, prudence, and care to the firm who hired her to serve as fund manager.
C. owes the duty of loyalty, prudence, and care to invest in a manner consistent with the stated mandate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2024.02-Ethics-Lin-09
entry.itemBody: Rebecca Chen, CFA, is a portfolio manager at an investment firm. Chen has been specializing in the technology sector. She recently expanded her coverage to the oil sector. Chen attends training to ensure that she has sufficient knowledge of the oil sector before taking the new role. After comprehensive research, Chen concludes that First Oil Company (FOC) is undervalued and buys FOC shares for her clients for whom the investment is suitable. Two months later, FOC's price declines by 20%. Has Chen violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.0282a291-5997-4dc1-8cb0-66b45ad9ec74: Incorrect because Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, states that members and candidates must  exercise diligence, independence, and thoroughness in analyzing investments, making investment recommendations, and taking investment actions. Chen has completed comprehensive research before buying the shares to her clients for whom the investment is suitable. Therefore, she has not violated the Standard V(A).
answerFeedback.508dab81-8791-4ecf-be6e-ed72d1ed3d53:
Correct because Standard I(E), Competence, states that to be competent in your role and meet your duties under this standard means having sufficient knowledge, skills, and abilities suitable for a professional to work in that specific role with success. These attributes govern the expertise, experience, and accomplishments that professionals need to perform at the highest level. While competence allows members and candidates the opportunity to undertake an activity successfully, lack of competence cannot necessarily be determined by an unsuccessful or a negative outcome. Many competent investment professionals have experienced failure or loss in their professional lives. Chen has obtained the knowledge in new area and completed a comprehensive research before buying the shares to her clients for whom the investment is suitable. Therefore, Chen has not violated Standard I(E) even though the stock price declined by 20%.

In addition, Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, states that members and candidates must exercise diligence, independence, and thoroughness in analyzing investments, making investment recommendations, and taking investment actions. Chen has completed comprehensive research before buying the shares to her clients for whom the investment is suitable. Therefore, she has also not violated the Standard V(A).
answerFeedback.b558b0c0-53d1-4095-ab82-fd733e27e50f: Incorrect because Standard I(E), Competence, states that to be competent in your role and meet your duties under this standard means having sufficient knowledge, skills, and abilities suitable for a professional to work in that specific role with success. These attributes govern the expertise, experience, and accomplishments that professionals need to perform at the highest level. While competence allows members and candidates the opportunity to undertake an activity successfully, lack of competence cannot necessarily be determined by an unsuccessful or a negative outcome. Many competent investment professionals have experienced failure or loss in their professional lives. Chen has obtained the knowledge in new area and completed a comprehensive research before buying the shares to her clients for whom the investment is suitable. Therefore, Chen has not violated Standard I(E) even though the stock price declined by 20%.

choices.itemBody: A. No
B. Yes, the Standard relating to competence
C. Yes, the Standard relating to diligence and reasonable basis

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Ethics-Ebeling-12
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following is among the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to misrepresentation?

  • Procedure 1: Each member should prepare for client distribution a list of services that the member is capable of performing.
  • Procedure 2: Members should cite specific quotations as attributable to 'investment experts' when confidentiality of the sources has to be preserved.

answerFeedback.177bc702-e8f7-4144-8853-4480716a0bfc: Incorrect because Standard I (C), Misrepresentation, states that misrepresentation through plagiarism in investment management can take various forms. Other practices include citing specific quotations as attributable to 'leading analysts' and 'investment experts' without naming the specific references. It is therefore not a recommended procedure for compliance to cite specific quotations as attributable to 'investment experts' without naming the sources to preserve confidentiality.
answerFeedback.2894ccc9-affa-462a-a0ef-296db4c3a634: Incorrect because Standard I (C), Misrepresentation, states that misrepresentation through plagiarism in investment management can take various forms. Other practices include citing specific quotations as attributable to 'leading analysts' and 'investment experts' without naming the specific references. It is therefore not a recommended procedure for compliance to cite specific quotations as attributable to 'investment experts' without naming the sources to preserve confidentiality.
answerFeedback.64ab1131-f1d3-4e6d-8235-ed59597efe65: Correct because the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I (C), Misrepresentation, state that to ensure accurate presentations to clients, each member and candidate should prepare a summary of his or her own qualifications and experience and a list of the services the member or candidate is capable of performing.

choices.itemBody: A. Procedure 1 only
B. Procedure 2 only
C. Both Procedure 1 and Procedure 2

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05808
entry.itemBody: According to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to misrepresentation, a member should:

answerFeedback.74018f5b-ca0f-44cd-87d5-15e8c1807887: Incorrect because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I (C), Misrepresentation, to ensure accurate presentations to clients, each member and candidate should prepare a summary of his or her own qualifications and experience and a list of the services the member or candidate is capable of performing. There is no recommendation to update qualifications at least quarterly.
answerFeedback.745bcae1-0dc9-44c8-aedf-84bb137964b5: Incorrect because there is no recommended procedure for compliance with Standard I (C), Misrepresentation, that suggests avoiding using third-party information. Rather, members and candidates should encourage their employers to develop procedures for verifying information of third-party firms.
